Recovering Labels from Local Updates in Federated Learning

Huancheng Chen    Haris Vikalo
Abstract

Gradient inversion (GI) attacks present a threat to the privacy of clients in federated learning (FL) by aiming to enable reconstruction of the clients’ data from communicated model updates. A number of such techniques attempts to accelerate data recovery by first reconstructing labels of the samples used in local training. However, existing label extraction methods make strong assumptions that typically do not hold in realistic FL settings. In this paper we present a novel label recovery scheme, Recovering Labels from Local Updates (RLU), which provides near-perfect accuracy when attacking untrained (most vulnerable) models. More significantly, RLU achieves high performance even in realistic real-world settings where the clients in an FL system run multiple local epochs, train on heterogeneous data, and deploy various optimizers to minimize different objective functions. Specifically, RLU estimates labels by solving a least-square problem that emerges from the analysis of the correlation between labels of the data points used in a training round and the resulting update of the output layer. The experimental results on several datasets, architectures, and data heterogeneity scenarios demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms existing baselines, and helps improve quality of the reconstructed images in GI attacks in terms of both PSNR and LPIPS.

Federated Learning, Label Recovery

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) (McMahan et al., 2017), which aims to enable collaborative training of ML models while protecting privacy of the participating clients, has attracted considerable interest in privacy-sensitive fields such as healthcare and finance (Yang et al., 2019). However, recent works have demonstrated vulnerability of FL systems to privacy attacks such as membership inference (Shokri et al., 2017), property inference (Melis et al., 2019) and gradient inversion (Zhu et al., 2019). In particular, gradient inversion methods have been shown capable of reconstructing private training data given the gradients computed during local training. The milestone work, Deep Leakage from Gradient (DLG) (Zhu et al., 2019), minimizes the difference between simulated and true gradients to extract data and the corresponding labels belonging to FL clients training a model for a classification task. However, DLG does not perform well in settings where the training batch size is large and the data resolution is high, since in such scenarios the joint optimization of data and the corresponding labels becomes challenging. A subsequent study, iDLG (Zhao et al., 2020), presents an analytical method for the recovery of ground-truth labels from the gradients by exploiting a relationship between the labels and the signs of the gradients. GradInversion (Yin et al., 2021) takes a step further by exploiting a relationship between labels and the magnitudes of gradient in the output layer to perfectly restore labels of the samples used in the considered training round, and facilitates high-resolution reconstruction of data in a batch with as many as 48 samples. Unfortunately, this method assumes no repeated labels in the batch, which is unrealistic in real-world settings. Recently, iRLG (Ma et al., 2023) attempted to address the limitations of GradInversion, enabling recovery of potentially repeated labels in a batch by utilizing gradients computed using a randomly initialized untrained model. However, the performance of iRLG drastically deteriorates as the model’s accuracy improves.

The above label recovery methods either: (1) assume no repeated labels in a batch; (2) use non-negative network activation functions; or (3) perform well only on untrained models. They further assume that each client in an FL system runs only a single epoch when updating its local model, while the more practical settings with multiple epochs of local training are not considered. Moreover, these studies are limited to the scenarios where a server collects gradients and do not apply to the standard FL setting where the server collects model updates rather than the gradients.

Aiming to address the aforementioned limitations of the prior work, in this paper we propose a novel method for label recovery, Recovering Labels from Local Updates (RLU). We start by analyzing correlations between local updates of the output layer and the ground-truth labels of data samples in training batches for several frequently used FL algorithms. These correlations, along with the expected value of the “erroneous confidence” (i.e., the level of confidence when making erroneous decisions) evaluated on a small auxiliary dataset, are then used to recover the labels. As local training unfolds across multiple epochs, distribution of the previously mentioned “erroneous confidence” undergoes changes which the server cannot access. Simulating an underlying dynamical model helps estimate how this distribution evolves across training epochs; the obtained estimates of intermediate distributions are then utilized to help achieve notable enhancement in the accuracy of label recovery. The effectiveness of RLU is demonstrated in extensive experiments involving several FL algorithms and various model architectures on SVHN, CIFAR10, CIFAR100 and Tiny-ImageNet datasets. In all the considered settings, RLU outperforms state-of-the-art baselines on both untrained and well-trained models. The main contributions of the paper are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We propose a general analytical method that enables the server in an FL system to recover labels of the points used by clients in local training; the proposed method applies to various FL algorithms and makes no assumptions regarding the activation function or batch label composition.

  • •

    To allow accurate label recovery in FL systems where clients train across multiple epochs, we simulate the evolution of the model through the epochs via a Monte Carlo method that updates the “erroneous confidence” characterizing the correlation between local updates and training data labels.

  • •

    To evaluate the proposed label recovery method, we conduct comprehensive benchmarking experiments across a number of FL settings where we vary the level of data heterogeneity, model architectures and local objective functions.

2 Preliminary and Related Work

Federated Learning. The classical FL algorithm, FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017), enables K𝐾K clients to collaboratively train global model without sharing their private data 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}. In FedAvg, the server initializes training round t𝑡t by broadcasting global model 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} to the clients. Client k𝑘k updates its local model by running a gradient descent procedure on its (private) local data; the server then collects updated local models 𝜽k(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k} from the clients and averages them to form a new global model,

𝜽(t+1)=∑k=1Kpk​𝜽k(t),superscript𝜽𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k}, (1)

where pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} denotes the weight assigned to client k𝑘k. Since the training is initialized by broadcasting global model 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} to the clients, local updates are computed as Δ​𝜽k(t)=𝜽k(t)−𝜽(t)Δsubscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝑘superscript𝜽𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}. It is worth pointing out that in FL algorithms other than FedAvg, Δ​𝜽k(t)Δsubscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝑘\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k} is not necessarily proportional to the gradients ∇𝜽k(t)∇subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝑘\nabla\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k}. We discuss properties of local updates in Section 3.3.

Gradients Inversion Attack. DLG (Zhu et al., 2019) is the first optimization-based method for reconstructing training data given the gradients ∇𝜽∇𝜽\nabla\boldsymbol{\theta} and model 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}. More specifically, DLG minimizes the difference between simulated and ground-truth gradients,

𝐱⋆,𝐲⋆=arg​min𝐱′,𝐲′⁡‖∇𝜽ℒtask​(𝜽,𝐱′,𝐲′)−∇𝜽‖2.superscript𝐱⋆superscript𝐲⋆argsubscriptsuperscript𝐱′superscript𝐲′superscriptnormsubscript∇𝜽subscriptℒtask𝜽superscript𝐱′superscript𝐲′∇𝜽2\mathbf{x}^{\star},\mathbf{y}^{\star}=\text{arg}\min_{\mathbf{x}^{\prime},\mathbf{y}^{\prime}}\left\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\text{task}}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},\mathbf{y}^{\prime})-\nabla\boldsymbol{\theta}\right\|^{2}. (2)

Follow-up studies (Geiping et al., 2020; Yin et al., 2021) introduced total variation and group consistency regularization to the objective of the gradient inversion optimization, enabling high reconstruction performance on ImageNet (Deng et al., 2009). Recently, a number of works (Jeon et al., 2021; Fang et al., 2023; Zhang et al., 2023) leveraged pre-trained generative models to improve the gradient inversion attack and achieve state-of-the-art performance with batch size set to 323232. However, these schemes assume knowing the ground-truth labels 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} in the batch – an unrealistic assumption that significantly accelerates the search for the optimal data 𝐱⋆superscript𝐱⋆\mathbf{x}^{\star}.

Label Recovery Attack. To improve the performance of an attack on gradients computed using samples coming from a relatively large batch, a series of studies (Zhao et al., 2020; Yin et al., 2021; Dang et al., 2021; Wainakh et al., 2021; Geng et al., 2021; Ma et al., 2023) proposed various analytical approaches to recovering labels 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} prior to solving the optimization over 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime}. However, all these methods suffer limitations that restrict their practical feasibility. GradInversion (Yin et al., 2021) assumes there are no repeated labels in a batch; RLG (Dang et al., 2021) can only recover class-wise labels but not instance-wise labels; LLG (Wainakh et al., 2021) and ZLG (Geng et al., 2021) require non-negative activation functions; iRLG (Ma et al., 2023) performs well only on randomly initialized untrained models. Moreover, these methods primarily focus on FedAvg and generally provide little if any discussion of other FL algorithms.

3 Methodology

3.1 Problem Settings

We consider multi-class classification models trained in FL settings where an honest-but-curious (HBC) server aims to recover ground-truth labels of the training samples using local updates Δ​𝜽k(t)Δsubscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝑘\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k} collected from clients while following a standard FL training procedure. The HBC server knows the batch size, number of local epochs and learning rate used by the clients but has no information about local data distribution. We assume each local model is trained by minimizing the cross-entropy (CE) loss

ℒce=−1|ℬ|​∑i=1|ℬ|log⁡exp⁡(𝐪y(i)(i))∑n=1Nexp⁡(𝐪n(i)),subscriptℒce1ℬsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1ℬsuperscriptsubscript𝐪superscript𝑦𝑖𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑛𝑖\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}=-\frac{1}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{B}|}\log\frac{\exp(\mathbf{q}_{y^{(i)}}^{(i)})}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\exp(\mathbf{q}_{n}^{(i)})}, (3)

where ℬℬ\mathcal{B} denotes a training batch; (𝐱(i),y(i))superscript𝐱𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖(\mathbf{x}^{(i)},y^{(i)}) is the i𝑖i-th example in the batch; N𝑁N is the number of classes; and 𝐪(i)=𝐖⋅𝐞(i)+𝐛superscript𝐪𝑖⋅𝐖superscript𝐞𝑖𝐛\mathbf{q}^{(i)}=\mathbf{W}\cdot\mathbf{e}^{(i)}+\mathbf{b} denotes the output logits of the model given the embedding 𝐞(i)∈ℝLsuperscript𝐞𝑖superscriptℝ𝐿\mathbf{e}^{(i)}\in\mathbb{R}^{L} of 𝐱(i)superscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}^{(i)}, where 𝐖∈ℝN×L𝐖superscriptℝ𝑁𝐿\mathbf{W}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times L} and 𝐛∈ℝN𝐛superscriptℝ𝑁\mathbf{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{N} are the weights and bias of the output layer.

3.2 Label Recovery from Local Updates (RLU)

Following the definition of the CE loss in Eq. 3, contribution of 𝐱(i)superscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}^{(i)} to the j𝑗j-th component of the gradient of 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} can be computed as (the proof provided in Appendix A.1)

∇𝐛j(i)={exp⁡(𝐪j(i))∑n=1Nexp⁡(𝐪n(i))=𝐬j​(𝐱(i)), if ​j≠y(i),−∑n≠jexp⁡(𝐪n(i))∑n=1Nexp⁡(𝐪n(i)), if ​j=y(i).\nabla\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(i)}=\left\{\begin{aligned} &\;\;\;\;\frac{\exp(\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)})}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\exp(\mathbf{q}_{n}^{(i)})}=\mathbf{s}_{j}(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}),\text{ if }j\not=y^{(i)},\\ &-\frac{\sum_{n\not=j}\exp(\mathbf{q}_{n}^{(i)})}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\exp(\mathbf{q}_{n}^{(i)})},\text{ if }j=y^{(i)}.\\ \end{aligned}\right. (4)

Assuming stochastic gradient descent (SGD) optimizer, the local update of the j𝑗j-th component of the output layer’s bias computed by client k𝑘k is

Δ​𝐛j=−η|ℬτ|​∑τ=1m∑i=1|ℬ|∇𝐛j(i,τ),ℬτ∼𝒟k,formulae-sequenceΔsubscript𝐛𝑗𝜂superscriptℬ𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1ℬ∇superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑖𝜏similar-tosuperscriptℬ𝜏subscript𝒟𝑘\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}=-\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}^{\tau}|}\sum_{\tau=1}^{m}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{B}|}\nabla\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(i,\tau)},\mathcal{B}^{\tau}\sim\mathcal{D}_{k}, (5)

where τ𝜏\tau is the local epoch index, m𝑚m is the number of epochs, η𝜂\eta is the learning rate, and 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} denotes client k𝑘k’s data. Note that 𝐬j​(𝐱(i))∈(0,1)subscript𝐬𝑗superscript𝐱𝑖01\mathbf{s}_{j}(\mathbf{x}^{(i)})\in(0,1) can be interpreted as the “erroneous confidence” of labeling 𝐱(i)superscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}^{(i)} as class j𝑗j while j≠y(i)𝑗superscript𝑦𝑖j\not=y^{(i)} (i.e., confidence in a labeling decision that is in fact erroneous). Let 𝒮n,jsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗\mathcal{S}_{n,j} denote the expected erroneous confidence for class j𝑗j given a sample with true label n≠j𝑛𝑗n\not=j,

𝒮n,j=𝔼(𝐱,y)∼𝒟k(n)​[𝐬j​(𝐱)],∀n,j∈[N]∧n≠j,formulae-sequencesubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑦superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑛delimited-[]subscript𝐬𝑗𝐱for-all𝑛𝑗delimited-[]𝑁𝑛𝑗\mathcal{S}_{n,j}=\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\mathcal{D}_{k}^{(n)}}\left[\mathbf{s}_{j}(\mathbf{x})\right],\forall n,j\in[N]\wedge n\not=j, (6)

where 𝒟k(n)⊆𝒟ksuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑛subscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}^{(n)}\subseteq\mathcal{D}_{k} collects samples with label n𝑛n and (𝐱,y)𝐱𝑦(\mathbf{x},y) is a random sample from 𝒟k(n)superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑛\mathcal{D}_{k}^{(n)}. These expectations are indicative of the model’s training error: 𝒮n,j≈1Nsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗1𝑁\mathcal{S}_{n,j}\approx\frac{1}{N} in a randomly initialized untrained model making random predictions, whereas 𝒮n,jsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗\mathcal{S}_{n,j} asymptotically goes to 00 as the accuracy of the model increases.

Note that the expected erroneous confidence, 𝒮n,jsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗\mathcal{S}_{n,j} does not admit closed-form expression; to analyze it and gain needed insight, we make the following assumption.

Assumption 3.1.

The output logits 𝐪(n)superscript𝐪𝑛\mathbf{q}^{(n)} of model 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} when the input is 𝐱∼𝒟(n)similar-to𝐱superscript𝒟𝑛\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{(n)} follows a multivariate normal distribution, i.e.,

𝐪(n)∼𝒩​(𝝁n,𝚺n),similar-tosuperscript𝐪𝑛𝒩subscript𝝁𝑛subscript𝚺𝑛\mathbf{q}^{(n)}\sim\mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n},\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{n}), (7)

where the mean 𝝁nsubscript𝝁𝑛\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n} and covariance 𝚺nsubscript𝚺𝑛\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{n} depend on the accuracy of the model.

For an untrained deep model whose parameters are initialized from a zero-mean uniform distribution, expected values of the output logits 𝝁1,…,𝝁Nsubscript𝝁1…subscript𝝁𝑁\boldsymbol{\mu}_{1},\dots,\boldsymbol{\mu}_{N} are approximately 𝟎0\mathbf{0}. As the accuracy of the model improves during the training process, 𝝁j,jsubscript𝝁𝑗𝑗\boldsymbol{\mu}_{j,j} converges to a positive value while 𝝁n,j​(n≠j)subscript𝝁𝑛𝑗𝑛𝑗\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}(n\not=j) converges to a negative value, forcing 𝒮n,jsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗\mathcal{S}_{n,j} to converge to 00. The existing methods that perform well only on untrained models operate under the assumption 𝝁n=𝟎subscript𝝁𝑛0\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}=\mathbf{0}, which does not hold for well-trained models. Experimental results that empirically verify Assumption 3.1 are provided in Appendix B.3.

In each global round of training, the server leverages global model 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} to obtain estimates of the parameters in (7), 𝝁¯nsubscript¯𝝁𝑛\bar{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n} and 𝚺¯nsubscript¯𝚺𝑛\bar{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{n}, via a Monte Carlo method run on a small auxiliary dataset 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}: the samples from 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} are processed by 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} and the resulting output logits are used to empirically compute the mean and variance. Given the estimates of the parameters, the server samples M𝑀M data points 𝐪(n,i)∼𝒩​(𝝁¯n,𝚺¯n)similar-tosuperscript𝐪𝑛𝑖𝒩subscript¯𝝁𝑛subscript¯𝚺𝑛\mathbf{q}^{(n,i)}\sim\mathcal{N}(\bar{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n},\bar{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{n}) to infer 𝒮n,jsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗\mathcal{S}_{n,j} as

𝒮¯n,j=1M​∑i=1Mexp⁡(𝐪j(n,i))∑c=1Nexp⁡(𝐪c(n,i)).subscript¯𝒮𝑛𝑗1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑛𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑐𝑛𝑖\bar{\mathcal{S}}_{n,j}=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{i=1}^{M}\frac{\exp(\mathbf{q}^{(n,i)}_{j})}{\sum_{c=1}^{N}\exp(\mathbf{q}_{c}^{(n,i)})}. (8)

3.2.1 Single Epoch Local Training

When m=1𝑚1m=1, we omit superscript τ𝜏\tau and let Δ​𝐛j=−η|ℬ|​∑i=1|ℬ|∇𝐛j(i)Δsubscript𝐛𝑗𝜂ℬsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1ℬ∇superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑖\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}=-\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{B}|}\nabla\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(i)}. By taking the expectation of Δ​𝐛jΔsubscript𝐛𝑗\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}, we obtain (details provided in Appendix A.3)

𝔼​[Δ​𝐛j]=η|ℬ|​(Nj​∑n≠j𝒮j,n−∑n≠jNn​𝒮n,j),𝔼delimited-[]Δsubscript𝐛𝑗𝜂ℬsubscript𝑁𝑗subscript𝑛𝑗subscript𝒮𝑗𝑛subscript𝑛𝑗subscript𝑁𝑛subscript𝒮𝑛𝑗\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}\right]=\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}|}\left(N_{j}\sum_{n\not=j}\mathcal{S}_{j,n}-\sum_{n\not=j}N_{n}\mathcal{S}_{n,j}\right), (9)

where Njsubscript𝑁𝑗N_{j} denotes the number of samples in ℬℬ\mathcal{B} with label j𝑗j. Finally, Njsubscript𝑁𝑗N_{j} is estimated by solving

s.t. 𝟎≤𝐳≤𝟏∧‖𝐳‖1=1,0𝐳1subscriptnorm𝐳11\displaystyle\mathbf{0}\leq\mathbf{z}\leq\mathbf{1}\wedge\left\|\mathbf{z}\right\|_{1}=1,

where 𝐮=Δ​𝐛/η𝐮Δ𝐛𝜂\mathbf{u}=\Delta\mathbf{b}/\eta, the diagonal entries of the coefficient matrix 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} are aj,j=∑n≠j𝒮j,nsubscript𝑎𝑗𝑗subscript𝑛𝑗subscript𝒮𝑗𝑛a_{j,j}=\sum_{n\not=j}\mathcal{S}_{j,n}, and the (n,j)𝑛𝑗(n,j) off-diagonal entry of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} is an,j=−𝒮n,jsubscript𝑎𝑛𝑗subscript𝒮𝑛𝑗a_{n,j}=-\mathcal{S}_{n,j}. After finding the solution 𝐳⋆superscript𝐳⋆\mathbf{z}^{\star} to the above problem, we estimate Njsubscript𝑁𝑗N_{j} as N¯j=⌊|ℬ|⋅𝐳j⋆⌉\bar{N}_{j}=\lfloor|\mathcal{B}|\cdot\mathbf{z}^{\star}_{j}\rceil.

3.2.2 Multiple Epochs of Local Training

To reduce communication bandwidth, clients in FL typically update their local models over multiple epochs (with multiple batches of data), as illustrated in Eq. 5. Assume fixed learning rate η𝜂\eta and constant batch size across all epochs (i.e., |ℬτ|=|ℬ|superscriptℬ𝜏ℬ|\mathcal{B}^{\tau}|=|\mathcal{B}| for all τ𝜏\tau); then the expectation of the local update 𝔼​[Δ​𝐛j(t)]𝔼delimited-[]Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t)}\right] in global round t𝑡t can be found as

η|ℬ|​∑τ=1m(Nj(t,τ)​∑n≠j𝒮j,n(t,τ)−∑n≠jNn(t,τ)​𝒮n,j(t,τ)),𝜂ℬsuperscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑡𝜏subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝜏subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑛𝑡𝜏superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{\tau=1}^{m}\left(N_{j}^{(t,\tau)}\sum_{n\not=j}\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,\tau)}-\sum_{n\not=j}N_{n}^{(t,\tau)}\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)}\right), (11)

where Nj(t,τ)superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑡𝜏N_{j}^{(t,\tau)} is the number of samples with label j𝑗j in epoch τ𝜏\tau and 𝒮n,j(t,τ)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)} denotes the expected erroneous confidence of local model 𝜽k(t,τ−1)superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡𝜏1\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t,\tau-1)} on class j𝑗j. At the beginning of local training, 𝜽k(t,0)subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡0𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t,0)}_{k} is initialized with the global model 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}. Note that 𝒮n,j(t,1)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡1\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,1)} can be estimated using global model 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} while 𝒮n,j(t,m+1)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡𝑚1\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,m+1)} is readily inferred using the collected local model 𝜽k(t,m)subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝑚𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t,m)}_{k} via previously described Monte Carlo procedure. However, the intermediate states 𝒮n,j(t,2),…,𝒮n,j(t,m)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡2…superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡𝑚\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,2)},\dots,\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,m)} are unknown since the server does not have access to local models 𝜽k(t,1),…,𝜽k(t,m−1)superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡1…superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡𝑚1\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t,1)},\dots,\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t,m-1)}. Since the evolution of 𝒮n,j(t,τ)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)} is non-linear, trivial interpolation between 𝒮j,n(t,1)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡1\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,1)} and 𝒮j,n(t,m+1)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝑚1\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,m+1)} may be highly inaccurate. To this end, we propose a practical method that relies on dynamics of the model parameter updates to approximate 𝒮j,n(t,τ)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝜏\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,\tau)} in the intermediate epochs. Suppose we know 𝒮j,n(t,τ)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝜏\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,\tau)} and the numbers of samples with different labels Nj(t,τ)superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑡𝜏N_{j}^{(t,\tau)}, j∈[N]𝑗delimited-[]𝑁j\in[N]. Then

𝔼​[Δ​𝐛j(t,τ)]=η|ℬ|​(Nj(t,τ)​∑n≠j𝒮j,n(t,τ)−∑n≠jNn(t,τ)​𝒮n,j(t,τ)).𝔼delimited-[]Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡𝜏𝜂ℬsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑡𝜏subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝜏subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑛𝑡𝜏superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t,\tau)}\right]=\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}|}\left(N_{j}^{(t,\tau)}\sum_{n\not=j}\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,\tau)}-\sum_{n\not=j}N_{n}^{(t,\tau)}\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)}\right). (12)

Since the gradients of the weights in the output layer satisfy ∇𝐖j,l=∇𝐛j⋅𝐞¯l∇subscript𝐖𝑗𝑙∇⋅subscript𝐛𝑗subscript¯𝐞𝑙\nabla\mathbf{W}_{j,l}=\nabla\mathbf{b}_{j}\cdot\bar{\mathbf{e}}_{l}, where 𝐞¯lsubscript¯𝐞𝑙\bar{\mathbf{e}}_{l} is the l𝑙l-th component of the average embedded signal, we can estimate the change of the output logit as (the proof is provided in Appendix A.2)

and then obtain 𝝁n,j(t,τ+1)=𝝁n,j(t,τ)+Δ​𝝁n,j(t,τ)superscriptsubscript𝝁𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏1superscriptsubscript𝝁𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏Δsuperscriptsubscript𝝁𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau+1)}=\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)}+\Delta\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)}. Using 𝝁n,j(t,τ+1)superscriptsubscript𝝁𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏1\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau+1)} in the next local epoch, one can estimate 𝒮n,j(t,τ+1)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏1\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau+1)} according to Eq. 8. By recursively conducting the above procedure, one can estimate all the intermediate states 𝒮n,j(t,τ)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)}. However, Nj(t,τ)superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑡𝜏N_{j}^{(t,\tau)} and 𝐞¯lsubscript¯𝐞𝑙\bar{\mathbf{e}}_{l} are not known – only the average updates of weight Δ​𝐖j,l(t)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐖𝑗𝑙𝑡\Delta\mathbf{W}_{j,l}^{(t)} and bias Δ​𝐛jtΔsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}^{t} are given. A closer examination of the correlation between ∇𝐖j,l(t)∇superscriptsubscript𝐖𝑗𝑙𝑡\nabla\mathbf{W}_{j,l}^{(t)} and ∇𝐛jt∇superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡\nabla\mathbf{b}_{j}^{t} suggests estimating the average embedded signal according to

𝐞¯l≈Δ​𝐖j,l(t)/Δ​𝐛j(t).subscript¯𝐞𝑙Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐖𝑗𝑙𝑡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡\bar{\mathbf{e}}_{l}\approx\Delta\mathbf{W}_{j,l}^{(t)}/\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t)}. (14)

To estimate the total number {N¯j(t)}j=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝑁𝑗𝑡𝑗1𝑁\{\bar{N}_{j}^{(t)}\}_{j=1}^{N} of labels in m𝑚m sampled batches we first set Nj(t,τ)=𝐠jsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑡𝜏subscript𝐠𝑗N_{j}^{(t,\tau)}=\mathbf{g}_{j}, where 𝐠∈ℕN𝐠superscriptℕ𝑁\mathbf{g}\in\mathbb{N}^{N} denotes an arbitrarily vector (a guess) satisfying ‖𝐠‖1=|ℬ|subscriptnorm𝐠1ℬ\left\|\mathbf{g}\right\|_{1}=|\mathcal{B}|. As described earlier in this subsection, if we knew Nj(t,τ)superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑡𝜏N_{j}^{(t,\tau)} we could dynamically update 𝒮j,n(t,τ)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝜏\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,\tau)} to arrive at 𝒮¯j,n(t,m+1)superscriptsubscript¯𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝑚1\bar{\mathcal{S}}_{j,n}^{(t,m+1)}. Since the true 𝒮j,n(t,m+1)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝑚1\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,m+1)} is known by the server (collected after the final epoch), the difference between 𝒮¯j,n(t,m+1)superscriptsubscript¯𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝑚1\bar{\mathcal{S}}_{j,n}^{(t,m+1)} and 𝒮j,n(t,m+1)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝑚1\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,m+1)} could be used to adjust 𝐠jsubscript𝐠𝑗\mathbf{g}_{j} and subsequently improve the estimate 𝒮¯j,n(t,m+1)superscriptsubscript¯𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝑚1\bar{\mathcal{S}}_{j,n}^{(t,m+1)}. If 𝒮¯j,n(t,m+1)superscriptsubscript¯𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝑚1\bar{\mathcal{S}}_{j,n}^{(t,m+1)} is significantly smaller than 𝒮j,n(t,m+1)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝑚1\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,m+1)}, 𝐠jsubscript𝐠𝑗\mathbf{g}_{j} was underestimated; otherwise, 𝐠jsubscript𝐠𝑗\mathbf{g}_{j} was overestimated. Intuitively, local model tends to label input data as class j𝑗j if the samples with label j𝑗j are dominant in the batches sampled for training.

After a number of iterations, the difference between 𝒮¯j,n(t,m+1)superscriptsubscript¯𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝑚1\bar{\mathcal{S}}_{j,n}^{(t,m+1)} and 𝒮j,n(t,m+1)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝑚1\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,m+1)} becomes small and m⋅𝐠j⋅𝑚subscript𝐠𝑗m\cdot\mathbf{g}_{j} closely approximates Nj(t)superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑡N_{j}^{(t)}. To accelerate the search for 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g}, one can introduce 𝒮¯j,n(t)=(𝒮j,n(t,1)+𝒮j,n(t,m+1))/2superscriptsubscript¯𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝑚12\bar{\mathcal{S}}_{j,n}^{(t)}=(\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,1)}+\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,m+1)})/2 and solve optimization (10) parameterized by 𝒮j,n=𝒮¯j,n(t)subscript𝒮𝑗𝑛superscriptsubscript¯𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡\mathcal{S}_{j,n}=\bar{\mathcal{S}}_{j,n}^{(t)} to obtain an initial estimate N¯j(t)superscriptsubscript¯𝑁𝑗𝑡\bar{N}_{j}^{(t)} which, in turn, is used to initialize 𝐠j=N¯j(t)/msubscript𝐠𝑗superscriptsubscript¯𝑁𝑗𝑡𝑚\mathbf{g}_{j}=\bar{N}_{j}^{(t)}/m. In our experiments, following such an initialization RLU achieves highly accurate performance after only T=5𝑇5T=5 iterations. The algorithms described in this section are formalized in Appendix C.1 and C.2.

3.3 FL schemes beyond FedAvg and SGD

The prior works on GI attacks in FL focused on FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017), where local training pursues minimization of the CE loss, ℒcesubscriptℒce\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}. Deterioration of the performance of FedAvg observed in non-i.i.d. settings motivated a number of studies (Li et al., 2020; Karimireddy et al., 2020; Acar et al., 2021; Gao et al., 2022; Chen et al., 2023; Chen & Vikalo, 2023a, b) that address the challenge of data heterogeneity by introducing various regularization terms to the local objective function. In particular, those methods consider objectives that are combination of the empirical risk and a regularizer, i.e.,

ℒlocal=ℒce+ℒregularizer.subscriptℒlocalsubscriptℒcesubscriptℒregularizer\mathcal{L}_{\text{local}}=\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}+\mathcal{L}_{\text{regularizer}}. (15)

For such objectives, the local updates of the bias collected by a server are not proportional to the gradients of ℒcesubscriptℒce\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}, adversely affecting the efficacy of the existing methods that attempt to recover labels from gradients. Furthermore, the existing label recovery methods assume that the local models are updated using SGD optimizers. When optimizers other than SGD are used, local updates are generally not proportional to the gradients of ℒcesubscriptℒce\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}. To explore such settings, we analyze the expectation of local updates in several milestone non-i.i.d. FL schemes and consider two well-known variants of SGD (Ruder, 2016), SGD with momentum (SGDm) and Nesterov accelerated gradient method (NAG). To accommodate these more general cases, we rephrase the expectation of the j𝑗j-th component of the local update of bias 𝔼​[Δ​𝐛j(t)]𝔼delimited-[]Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t)}\right] in global round t𝑡t as

η|ℬ|​∑τ=1mρ(τ)​(Nj(t,τ)​∑n≠j𝒮j,n(t,τ)−∑n≠jNn(t,τ)​𝒮n,j(t,τ))−𝐡j(t),𝜂ℬsuperscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑚superscript𝜌𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑡𝜏subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝜏subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑛𝑡𝜏superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{\tau=1}^{m}\rho^{(\tau)}\left(N_{j}^{(t,\tau)}\sum_{n\not=j}\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,\tau)}-\sum_{n\not=j}N_{n}^{(t,\tau)}\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)}\right)-\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)}, (16)

where ρ(τ)superscript𝜌𝜏\rho^{(\tau)} is a constant that depends on hyper-parameters used by different methods and remains constant across global rounds, and 𝐡j(t)superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)} is a term capturing historical training information (past local updates). We summarize the values of ρ(τ)superscript𝜌𝜏\rho^{(\tau)} and 𝐡j(t)superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)} for different FL schemes in Table 1 (derivations provided in Appendix A.4-A.9). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that studies label recovery attacks in FL schemes beyond FedAvg. In FL schemes that utilize only the gradient information computed in the current global round (e.g., FedAvg and FedProx) 𝐡jt=𝟎superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡0\mathbf{h}_{j}^{t}=\mathbf{0}, while for the schemes that also rely on the past gradient information (Scaffold, FedDyn and FedDC) 𝐡jt≠𝟎superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡0\mathbf{h}_{j}^{t}\not=\mathbf{0}. In any case, ρ(τ)superscript𝜌𝜏\rho^{(\tau)} and 𝐡j(t)superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)} are known to the server and may potentially be used for label recovery attacks. In our work, we rely on the procedure for label recovery from local updates discussed in the previous section to run RLU attacks on different FL schemes where ρ(τ)superscript𝜌𝜏\rho^{(\tau)} and 𝐡jtsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{t} vary from one scheme to another according to Table 1.

4 Experiments

4.1 Setups

We evaluate the performance of RLU on a classification task using a variety of model architectures including LeNet-5 (LeCun et al., 1998), VGG-16 (Simonyan & Zisserman, 2014) and ResNet-50 (He et al., 2016), and four benchmark datasets including SVHN (Netzer et al., 2011), CIFAR10, CIFAR100 and Tiny-ImageNet (Le & Yang, 2015). Throughout these experiments we employ a number of activation functions including ReLU, Tanh, ELU (Clevert et al., 2015), SELU (Klambauer et al., 2017) and SiLU (Elfwing et al., 2018) to further evaluate robustness of our proposed method. To simulate diverse FL scenarios, we follow the strategy in (Yurochkin et al., 2019) and utilize Dirichlet distribution with a concentration parameter α𝛼\alpha, controlling the level of data heterogeneity across 101010 data partitions owned by 10 clients. Unless specified otherwise, the models are trained using SGD optimizers. The auxiliary dataset 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} contains 100100100 samples per class. Further experimental details are provided in Appendix B.2.

4.2 Baselines and Evaluation Metrics

We compare our proposed RLU to three state-of-the-art methods: LLG (Wainakh et al., 2021), ZLG (Geng et al., 2021) and iRLG (Ma et al., 2023), all capable of recovering repeated labels in a batch. For fairness, we compare RLU to LLG+ and ZLG+; the latter two utilize the same auxiliary dataset 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} as RLU to achieve improved performance. Following the strategy of iRLG, we quantify the performance of a label recovery attack using two metrics: (1) class-level accuracy (cAcc): the proportion of correctly recovered classes; (2) instance-level accuracy (iAcc): the proportion of correctly recovered labels. Details of computing cAcc and iAcc are provided in Appendix B.4. We recover batch labels from the local updates computed on clients’ local dataset and report the average cAcc and iAcc.

4.3 Attack on Untrained Models

A randomly initialized untrained model may be extremely vulnerable to label recovery attacks; for instance, if the server knows how the training is initialized, it does not even need an auxiliary data set to infer the parameters (e.g., 𝝁nsubscript𝝁𝑛\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}) used in the attack. To compare the performance of baseline methods with that of RLU, we conduct comprehensive experiments on untrained models across various architectures, datasets, batch-sizes and activation functions. The results, reported in Table 2, demonstrate that RLU outperforms the baselines in all settings. When local training consists of a single epoch, RLU achieves near-perfect accuracy across the board in terms of both cAcc and iAcc; iRLG is a close second, outperforming other baselines. Since LLG+ assumes non-negative activation functions, its performance deteriorates significantly with Tanh and SELU. On Tiny-ImageNet, ZLG+ performs the worst among the four methods, achieving under 70%percent7070\% iAcc.

When the clients run m=10𝑚10m=10 local epochs, performance of all methods deteriorates (as expected based on the discussion in Section 3.2.2). Nevertheless, the results in Table 2 show that RLU still outperforms the baselines, maintaining at least 84%percent8484\% cACC and 90%percent9090\% iAcc on all datasets, architectures and activation functions. While iRLG maintains solid performance on SVHN and Tiny-ImageNet, it performs significantly worse on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 (iAcc falls below 70%percent7070\%, cAcc drops below 50%percent5050\%). The results of LLG+ follow the same pattern exhibited in single epoch settings, while ZLG+ experiences significant performance deterioration on SVHN. For consistency and a comparison with the results in Table 2, unless stated otherwise, in the remainder of this section the number of local epochs m𝑚m is set to 101010.

4.4 Attack on Trained Models

Since the accuracy of the global model improves as the training proceeds, comparing methods in terms of attacks on untrained model becomes no longer meaningful. As discussed in Section 3.2, distribution of output logits depends on the accuracy of the model which is parameterized by mean 𝝁nsubscript𝝁𝑛\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n} and covariance 𝚺nsubscript𝚺𝑛\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{n}. When the model becomes highly accurate, magnitudes of local gradients (updates) start vanishing; this, in turn, causes high sensitivity to noise and a large error in estimating the labels. All of the methods in Table 2 experience performance deterioration as the model accuracy increases. To compare their robustness, we conduct extensive experiments and evaluate performance of different attack methods at different stages of training. As shown in Fig. 1, RLU outperforms the baselines at all training stages, achieving 80%percent8080\% iAcc when the model accuracy reaches 80%percent8080\%. For the global model achieving 90%percent9090\% training accuracy, iAcc of iRLG reaches 75.6%percent75.675.6\%, 83.3%percent83.383.3\% and 72.6%percent72.672.6\% on SVHN, CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. The iAcc of ZLG+ is 33.3%percent33.333.3\%, 21.1%percent21.121.1\% and 30.1%percent30.130.1\% lower than RLU’s, while iRLG’s trails RLU by 16.3%percent16.316.3\%, 17.3%percent17.317.3\% and 23.9%percent23.923.9\% on these three datasets, respectively. The iAcc performance of LLG+ is better than that of other prior methods but still falls significantly behind RLU’s.

4.5 Effect of Data Heterogeneity

Data heterogeneity is one the main challenges in real-world applications of federated learning. Prior works on label reconstruction evaluated their proposed methods on i.i.d. data, but the evaluation on non-i.i.d. data has remained largely unexplored. To this end, we benchmark the methods considered in this paper on CIFAR10 data partitions generated for varied values of α={0.05,0.1,0.5,1,5}𝛼0.050.10.515\alpha=\{0.05,0.1,0.5,1,5\} (smaller α𝛼\alpha corresponds to higher level of heterogeneity). We visualize the generated data partitions in Appendix B.5. Table LABEL:table3 shows that iAcc of the three baselines monotonically decreases with the level of data heterogeneity. On the other hand, RLU demonstrate a great degree of robustness as it maintains high iAcc across the board; in particular, RLU achieves 93%percent9393\% or higher instance-level accuracy in all settings, including at the highest level of data heterogeneity (α=0.05𝛼0.05\alpha=0.05).

4.6 Effect of the Size of Auxiliary Dataset 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}

As previously discussed, RLU needs an auxiliary dataset 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} to estimate moments of the output logits distribution. In the benchmarking experiments presented thus far, we used 100100100 samples for each class in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. To analyze the effect of the size of auxiliary dataset on the performance of RLU, we conduct 444 sets of experiments that utilize 444 auxiliary datasets with: (1) 555 samples per class; (2) 101010 samples per class; (3) 505050 samples per class; and (4) 100100100 samples per class. As shown in Fig. 2, there appears to be no significant performance degradation due to reduction of the auxiliary data set size. When using the smallest among the auxiliary sets, on SVHN and Tiny the proposed RLU achieves performance close to the baseline. The largest performance gap is on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, and even there the gap is only 2.4%percent2.42.4\% and 3.1%percent3.13.1\%, respectively. Therefore, RLU exhibits robustness with respect to the variations in the size of the auxiliary data set used by the server.

4.7 Attacks on Different FL Schemes

To the best of our knowledge, prior works evaluate their methods only on FedAvg. While FedAvg is indeed the oldest and perhaps the most widely used FL scheme, a number of other FL schemes has grown to prominence yet remains largely unexplored in the context of label recovery. As discussed in Section 3.3, we provide a framework to conduct label recovery attacks on several regularization-based FL schemes that may be using various optimizers. Table 4 shows the superior performance of RLU in the experiments on FedProx and SGDm. As can be seen from the table, in the experiments where λ=0.5𝜆0.5\lambda=0.5 and γ=0.1𝛾0.1\gamma=0.1 (which leads to ρ(τ)≈1superscript𝜌𝜏1\rho^{(\tau)}\approx 1), the three baselines achieve performance similar to that in their attacks on FedAvg. However, as ρ(τ)superscript𝜌𝜏\rho^{(\tau)} deviates from 111 when λ=5𝜆5\lambda=5 and γ=0.9𝛾0.9\gamma=0.9, performance of the baselines severely deteriorates while RLU maintain its iAcc of at least 88%percent8888\%.

4.8 Improved Gradient Inversion Attacks with RLU

The outstanding performance of RLU on label recovery can improve the gradient inversion attacks in federated learning. In the prior work IG (Geiping et al., 2020), an HBC server performs joint optimization of the reconstructed labels 𝐲′superscript𝐲′\mathbf{y}^{\prime} and images 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime}, which typically results in slow convergence and poor quality of the reconstructed images. We conduct gradients inversion attack experiments on CIFAR10, where we use RLU to estimate labels 𝐲′superscript𝐲′\mathbf{y}^{\prime} from local updates and only optimize the reconstructed images 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} according to Eq. 2. To quantitatively characterize the quality of reconstructed images, we compute the peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) and the learned perceptual image patch similarity (LPIPS) (Zhang et al., 2018) of the reconstructed images in each batch. As illustrated in Fig. 3, images reconstructed with the help of RLU have higher PSNR and lower LPIPS, indicating smaller distance to the original images.

5 Conclusion

In this paper, we studied label recovery attacks on federated learning systems in which clients send their local model updates to the server for aggregation. We developed RLU, a novel label recovery method which solves a least-square problem constructed by examining the correlation between the number of samples of each label type and local updates of the output layer. We extended the proposed framework to real-world scenarios involving well-trained models, multiple local epochs, high levels of data heterogeneity and various local objective functions, and provided theoretical analysis of RLU in different FL schemes. Comprehensive experiments on four datasets, three model architectures and six activation functions demonstrate consistently high accuracy, robustness and universality of RLU. Moreover, gradients inversion attack experiments illustrate that utilizing RLU may significantly improve quality of the reconstructed data in term of two widely-used metrics, PSNR and LPIPS. Future work will include exploring defense mechanism that may help ameliorate safety concerns caused by RLU.

Appendix A Proof of Analytical Results

A.1 Derivation of the gradient of the output layer’s bias 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b}

Given a batch of samples (𝐱(i),y(i))∈ℬsuperscript𝐱𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖ℬ(\mathbf{x}^{(i)},y^{(i)})\in\mathcal{B}, the cross-entrop loss can be computed as

ℒce==1|ℬ|∑i=1|ℬ|ℒce(i)=−1|ℬ|∑i=1|ℬ|logexp⁡(𝐪y(i)(i))∑n=1Nexp⁡(𝐪n(i)),\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}==\frac{1}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{B}|}\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(i)}=-\frac{1}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{B}|}\log\frac{\exp(\mathbf{q}_{y^{(i)}}^{(i)})}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\exp(\mathbf{q}_{n}^{(i)})}, (17)
𝐪j(i)=∑l=1L𝐖j,l​𝐳l(i)+𝐛j,superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝐿subscript𝐖𝑗𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑙𝑖subscript𝐛𝑗\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)}=\sum_{l=1}^{L}\mathbf{W}_{j,l}\mathbf{z}_{l}^{(i)}+\mathbf{b}_{j}, (18)

where N𝑁N is the number of classes; 𝐪j(i)superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑗𝑖\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)} denotes the j𝑗j-th component of output logits given sample 𝐱(i)superscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}^{(i)}; 𝐖j,lsubscript𝐖𝑗𝑙\mathbf{W}_{j,l} is the (j,l)𝑗𝑙(j,l)-element of weights of the output layer; 𝐛jsubscript𝐛𝑗\mathbf{b}_{j} is the j𝑗j-th component of bias of the output layer; 𝐳(i)superscript𝐳𝑖\mathbf{z}^{(i)} is the embedding of data 𝐱(i)superscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}^{(i)}; L𝐿L is the dimension of embedding space. The gradient of the bias 𝐛jsubscript𝐛𝑗\mathbf{b}_{j} given sample (𝐱(i),y(i))superscript𝐱𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖(\mathbf{x}^{(i)},y^{(i)}) can be computed using the chain rule as

∂ℒce(i)∂𝐛j=∂ℒce(i)∂𝐐⋅∂𝐐∂𝐪j(i)⋅∂𝐪j(i)∂𝐛j,superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑖subscript𝐛𝑗⋅superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑖𝐐𝐐superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑗𝑖subscript𝐛𝑗\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(i)}}{\partial\mathbf{b}_{j}}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(i)}}{\partial\mathbf{Q}}\cdot\frac{\partial\mathbf{Q}}{\partial\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)}}\cdot\frac{\partial\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)}}{\partial\mathbf{b}_{j}}, (19)

where

𝐐=exp⁡(𝐪y(i)(i))∑n=1Nexp⁡(𝐪n(i)).𝐐superscriptsubscript𝐪superscript𝑦𝑖𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑛𝑖\mathbf{Q}=\frac{\exp(\mathbf{q}_{y^{(i)}}^{(i)})}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\exp(\mathbf{q}_{n}^{(i)})}. (20)

To start, note that

∂ℒce(i)∂𝐐=−1𝐐,∂𝐪j(i)∂𝐛j=1.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptℒce𝑖𝐐1𝐐superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑗𝑖subscript𝐛𝑗1\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(i)}}{\partial\mathbf{Q}}=-\frac{1}{\mathbf{Q}},\frac{\partial\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)}}{\partial\mathbf{b}_{j}}=1. (21)

If j=y(i)𝑗superscript𝑦𝑖j=y^{(i)}, we obtain

∂𝐐∂𝐪j(i)=exp(𝐪y(i)(i))(∑n=1Nexp(𝐪n(i)))−exp(𝐪y(i)(i))2(∑n=1Nexp⁡(𝐪n(i)))2=∑n≠y(i)exp⁡(𝐪n(i))∑n=1Nexp⁡(𝐪n(i))⋅𝐐,\frac{\partial\mathbf{Q}}{\partial\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)}}=\frac{\exp\left(\mathbf{q}^{(i)}_{y^{(i)}}\right)\left(\sum_{n=1}^{N}\exp\left(\mathbf{q}^{(i)}_{n}\right)\right)-\exp\left(\mathbf{q}^{(i)}_{y^{(i)}}\right)^{2}}{\left(\sum_{n=1}^{N}\exp\left(\mathbf{q}^{(i)}_{n}\right)\right)^{2}}=\frac{\sum_{n\not=y^{(i)}}\exp\left(\mathbf{q}^{(i)}_{n}\right)}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\exp\left(\mathbf{q}^{(i)}_{n}\right)}\cdot\mathbf{Q}, (22)

while if j≠y(i)𝑗superscript𝑦𝑖j\not=y^{(i)},

∂𝐐∂𝐪j(i)=−exp⁡(𝐪y(i)(i))​exp⁡(𝐪i(i))(∑n=1Nexp⁡(𝐪n(i)))2=−exp⁡(𝐪i(i))∑n=1Nexp⁡(𝐪n(i))⋅𝐐.𝐐superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑗𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖superscript𝑦𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖𝑖superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖𝑛2⋅subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖𝑛𝐐\frac{\partial\mathbf{Q}}{\partial\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)}}=-\frac{\exp\left(\mathbf{q}^{(i)}_{y^{(i)}}\right)\exp\left(\mathbf{q}^{(i)}_{i}\right)}{\left(\sum_{n=1}^{N}\exp\left(\mathbf{q}^{(i)}_{n}\right)\right)^{2}}=-\frac{\exp\left(\mathbf{q}^{(i)}_{i}\right)}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\exp\left(\mathbf{q}^{(i)}_{n}\right)}\cdot\mathbf{Q}. (23)

By substituting Eq. 22 and Eq. 23 in Eq. 19, we obtain

∇𝐛j(i)={exp⁡(𝐪j(i))∑n=1Nexp⁡(𝐪n(i)), if ​j≠y(i),−∑n≠jexp⁡(𝐪n(i))∑n=1Nexp⁡(𝐪n(i)), if ​j=y(i).\nabla\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(i)}=\left\{\begin{aligned} &\frac{\exp(\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)})}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\exp(\mathbf{q}_{n}^{(i)})},\text{ if }j\not=y^{(i)},\\ &-\frac{\sum_{n\not=j}\exp(\mathbf{q}_{n}^{(i)})}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\exp(\mathbf{q}_{n}^{(i)})},\text{ if }j=y^{(i)}.\\ \end{aligned}\right. (24)

■■\hfill\blacksquare

A.2 Derivation of the gradient of the output layer’s weight 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W}

According to Eq. 17 and Eq. 18, gradients of the weight 𝐖j,lsubscript𝐖𝑗𝑙\mathbf{W}_{j,l} given sample (𝐱(i),𝐲(i))superscript𝐱𝑖superscript𝐲𝑖(\mathbf{x}^{(i)},\mathbf{y}^{(i)}) can be computed as

∂ℒce(i)∂𝐖j,l=∂ℒce(i)∂𝐐⋅∂𝐐∂𝐪j(i)⋅∂𝐪j(i)∂𝐖j,l.superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑖subscript𝐖𝑗𝑙⋅superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑖𝐐𝐐superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑗𝑖subscript𝐖𝑗𝑙\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(i)}}{\partial\mathbf{W}_{j,l}}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(i)}}{\partial\mathbf{Q}}\cdot\frac{\partial\mathbf{Q}}{\partial\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)}}\cdot\frac{\partial\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)}}{\partial\mathbf{W}_{j,l}}. (25)

Since, as discussed in Section A.1, we know ∂ℒce(i)∂𝐐superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑖𝐐\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(i)}}{\partial\mathbf{Q}} and ∂𝐐∂𝐪j(i)𝐐superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑗𝑖\frac{\partial\mathbf{Q}}{\partial\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)}}, we have ∂𝐪j(i)∂𝐖j,l=𝐳j(i)superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑗𝑖subscript𝐖𝑗𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑗𝑖\frac{\partial\mathbf{q}_{j}^{(i)}}{\partial\mathbf{W}_{j,l}}=\mathbf{z}_{j}^{(i)}. Finally, we obtain

∇𝐖j,l(i)=∇𝐛j(i)⋅𝐳l(i).∇superscriptsubscript𝐖𝑗𝑙𝑖∇⋅superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑙𝑖\nabla\mathbf{W}_{j,l}^{(i)}=\nabla\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(i)}\cdot\mathbf{z}_{l}^{(i)}. (26)

■■\hfill\blacksquare

A.3 Derivation of the expected local update of the output layer’s bias 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} (single epoch)

Δ​𝐛j=−η​∇𝐛j=−η|ℬ|​∑i=1|ℬ|∇𝐛j(i).Δsubscript𝐛𝑗𝜂∇subscript𝐛𝑗𝜂ℬsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1ℬ∇superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑖\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}=-\eta\nabla\mathbf{b}_{j}=-\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{B}|}\nabla\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(i)}. (27)

𝔼​[Δ​𝐛j]𝔼delimited-[]Δsubscript𝐛𝑗\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}\right] =−η|ℬ|​∑i=1|ℬ|𝔼​[∇𝐛j(i)]absent𝜂ℬsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1ℬ𝔼delimited-[]∇superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑖\displaystyle=-\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{B}|}\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(i)}\right] (28)

A.4 Derivation of the expected local update using SGD with momentum (SGDm)

In each local epoch τ𝜏\tau, SGD with momentum (Ruder, 2016) updates the model parameters θk(t,τ)subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝜏𝑘\theta^{(t,\tau)}_{k} of client k𝑘k according to

𝐯k(t,τ)←γ​𝐯k(t,τ−1)+∇ℒce(t,τ),absent←subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏1𝑘∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝜏\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k}\xleftarrow{}\gamma\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau-1)}_{k}+\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,\tau)}, (34)
θk(t,τ)←θk(t,τ−1)−η​𝐯k(t,τ),absent←subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝜏𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝜏1𝑘𝜂subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘\theta^{(t,\tau)}_{k}\xleftarrow{}\theta^{(t,\tau-1)}_{k}-\eta\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k}, (35)

where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate in global round t𝑡t; 𝐯(t,τ)superscript𝐯𝑡𝜏\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)} is the momentum in local epoch τ𝜏\tau; γ∈(0,1)𝛾01\gamma\in(0,1) is the momentum weight. Then the local update of client k𝑘k takes form

Δ​θk(t)=−η​∑τ=1m𝐯k(t,τ).Δsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑘𝜂superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘\Delta\theta^{(t)}_{k}=-\eta\sum_{\tau=1}^{m}\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k}. (36)

We can compute 𝐯k(t,τ)subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k} in Eq. 34 by mathematical induction, with 𝐯k(t,1)subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡1𝑘\mathbf{v}^{(t,1)}_{k} initialized as ∇ℒce(t,1)∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡1\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,1)}. In the following, we will prove that

𝐯k(t,τ)=∑i=1τγτ−i​∇ℒce(t,i).subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏superscript𝛾𝜏𝑖∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝑖\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\gamma^{\tau-i}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,i)}. (37)

Proof: According to Eq. 34,

𝐯k(t,2)=γ​𝐯k(t,1)+∇ℒce(t,2)=γ​∇ℒce(t,1)+∇ℒce(t,2),subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡2𝑘𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡1𝑘∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡2𝛾∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡1∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡2\mathbf{v}^{(t,2)}_{k}=\gamma\mathbf{v}^{(t,1)}_{k}+\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,2)}=\gamma\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,1)}+\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,2)}, (38)
𝐯k(t,3)=γ​𝐯k(t,2)+∇ℒce(t,3)=γ2​∇ℒce(t,1)+γ​∇ℒce(t,2)+∇ℒce(t,3),subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡3𝑘𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡2𝑘∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡3superscript𝛾2∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡1𝛾∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡2∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡3\mathbf{v}^{(t,3)}_{k}=\gamma\mathbf{v}^{(t,2)}_{k}+\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,3)}=\gamma^{2}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,1)}+\gamma\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,2)}+\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,3)}, (39)

both satisfying Eq. 37. Assuming that for any τ≥2𝜏2\tau\geq 2

𝐯k(t,τ)=∑i=1τγτ−i​∇ℒce(t,i),subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏superscript𝛾𝜏𝑖∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝑖\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\gamma^{\tau-i}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,i)}, (40)

we can obtain 𝐯k(t,τ+1)subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏1𝑘\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau+1)}_{k} by following Eq. 34,

𝐯k(t,τ+1)subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏1𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau+1)}_{k} =γ​𝐯k(t,τ)+∇ℒce(t,τ+1)absent𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝜏1\displaystyle=\gamma\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k}+\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,\tau+1)} (41)
=∑i=1τγτ+1−i​∇ℒce(t,i)+∇ℒce(t,τ+1)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏superscript𝛾𝜏1𝑖∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝑖∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝜏1\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\gamma^{\tau+1-i}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,i)}+\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,\tau+1)}
=∑i=1τ+1γτ+1−i​∇ℒce(t,i),absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏1superscript𝛾𝜏1𝑖∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝑖\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{\tau+1}\gamma^{\tau+1-i}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,i)},

which proves our claim in Eq. 37. Thus we have

Δ​θk(t)=−η​∑τ=1m∑i=1τγτ−i​∇ℒce(t,i).Δsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑘𝜂superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏superscript𝛾𝜏𝑖∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝑖\Delta\theta^{(t)}_{k}=-\eta\sum_{\tau=1}^{m}\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\gamma^{\tau-i}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,i)}. (42)

Similar to the discussion regarding updating bias in the output layer, we obtain

𝔼​[Δ​𝐛j(t)]=η|ℬ|​∑τ=1m∑i=1τγτ−i​(Nj(t,τ)​∑n≠j𝒮j,n(t,τ)−∑n≠jNn(t,τ)​𝒮n,j(t,τ)).𝔼delimited-[]Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡𝜂ℬsuperscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏superscript𝛾𝜏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑡𝜏subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝜏subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑛𝑡𝜏superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t)}\right]=\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{\tau=1}^{m}\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\gamma^{\tau-i}\left(N_{j}^{(t,\tau)}\sum_{n\not=j}\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,\tau)}-\sum_{n\not=j}N_{n}^{(t,\tau)}\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)}\right). (43)

Reformulating Eq. 43 yields

𝔼​[Δ​𝐛j(t)]=η|ℬ|​∑τ=1mρ(τ)​(Nj(t,τ)​∑n≠j𝒮j,n(t,τ)−∑n≠jNn(t,τ)​𝒮n,j(t,τ)),𝔼delimited-[]Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡𝜂ℬsuperscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑚superscript𝜌𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑡𝜏subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑗𝑛𝑡𝜏subscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑛𝑡𝜏superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t)}\right]=\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{\tau=1}^{m}\rho^{(\tau)}\left(N_{j}^{(t,\tau)}\sum_{n\not=j}\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,\tau)}-\sum_{n\not=j}N_{n}^{(t,\tau)}\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)}\right), (44)

where

ρ(τ)=1−γm+1−τ1−γ.superscript𝜌𝜏1superscript𝛾𝑚1𝜏1𝛾\rho^{(\tau)}=\frac{1-\gamma^{m+1-\tau}}{1-\gamma}. (45)

A.5 Derivation of the expected local update using Nesterov accelerated gradient method (NAG)

In each local epoch τ𝜏\tau, Nesterov’s accelerated gradient method (Ruder, 2016) updates the model parameters θk(t,τ)subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝜏𝑘\theta^{(t,\tau)}_{k} of client k𝑘k according to

𝐯k(t,τ)←γ​𝐯k(t,τ−1)+∇ℒce(t,τ)+γ​(∇ℒce(t,τ)−∇ℒce(t,τ−1)),absent←subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏1𝑘∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝜏𝛾∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝜏∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝜏1\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k}\xleftarrow{}\gamma\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau-1)}_{k}+\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,\tau)}+\gamma\left(\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,\tau)}-\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,\tau-1)}\right), (46)
θk(t,τ)←θk(t,τ−1)−η​𝐯k(t,τ),absent←subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝜏𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝜏1𝑘𝜂subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘\theta^{(t,\tau)}_{k}\xleftarrow{}\theta^{(t,\tau-1)}_{k}-\eta\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k}, (47)

where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate in global round t𝑡t; 𝐯(t,τ)superscript𝐯𝑡𝜏\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)} is the momentum in local epoch τ𝜏\tau; γ∈(0,1)𝛾01\gamma\in(0,1) is the momentum weight. We form the local update of client k𝑘k as

Δ​θk(t)=−η​∑τ=1m𝐯k(t,τ).Δsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑘𝜂superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘\Delta\theta^{(t)}_{k}=-\eta\sum_{\tau=1}^{m}\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k}. (48)

One can compute 𝐯k(t,τ)subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k} according to Eq. 46 via mathematical induction, where 𝐯k(t,1)subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡1𝑘\mathbf{v}^{(t,1)}_{k} is initialized as (1+γ)​∇ℒce(t,1)1𝛾∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡1(1+\gamma)\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,1)}. In the following, we will prove that

𝐯k(t,τ)=∑i=1τ−1γτ−i+1​∇ℒce(t,i)+(1+γ)​∇ℒce(t,τ),τ≥2.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏1superscript𝛾𝜏𝑖1∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝑖1𝛾∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝜏𝜏2\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{\tau-1}\gamma^{\tau-i+1}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,i)}+(1+\gamma)\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,\tau)},\tau\geq 2. (49)

Proof: According to Eq. 46,

𝐯k(t,2)subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡2𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{v}^{(t,2)}_{k} =γ​𝐯k(t,1)+∇ℒce(t,2)+γ​(∇ℒce(t,2)−∇ℒce(t,1))absent𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡1𝑘∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡2𝛾∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡2∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡1\displaystyle=\gamma\mathbf{v}^{(t,1)}_{k}+\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,2)}+\gamma\left(\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,2)}-\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,1)}\right) (50)
=γ2​∇ℒce(t,1)+(1+γ)​∇ℒce(t,2),absentsuperscript𝛾2∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡11𝛾∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡2\displaystyle=\gamma^{2}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,1)}+(1+\gamma)\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,2)},
𝐯k(t,3)subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡3𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{v}^{(t,3)}_{k} =γ​𝐯k(t,2)+∇ℒce(t,3)+γ​(∇ℒce(t,3)−∇ℒce(t,2))absent𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡2𝑘∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡3𝛾∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡3∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡2\displaystyle=\gamma\mathbf{v}^{(t,2)}_{k}+\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,3)}+\gamma\left(\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,3)}-\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,2)}\right) (51)
=γ3​∇ℒce(t,1)+γ2​∇ℒce(t,2)+(1+γ)​∇ℒce(t,3),absentsuperscript𝛾3∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡1superscript𝛾2∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡21𝛾∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡3\displaystyle=\gamma^{3}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,1)}+\gamma^{2}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,2)}+(1+\gamma)\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,3)},

both satisfying Eq. 49. Assuming that for any τ≥2𝜏2\tau\geq 2

𝐯k(t,τ)=∑i=1τ−1γτ−i+1​∇ℒce(t,i)+(1+γ)​∇ℒce(t,τ),subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏1superscript𝛾𝜏𝑖1∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝑖1𝛾∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝜏\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau)}_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{\tau-1}\gamma^{\tau-i+1}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,i)}+(1+\gamma)\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,\tau)}, (52)

we obtain 𝐯k(t,τ+1)subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝜏1𝑘\mathbf{v}^{(t,\tau+1)}_{k} according to Eq. 46 as

Δ​θk(t)=−η​∑τ=2m(∑i=1τ−1γτ−i+1​∇ℒce(t,i))−η​(1+γ)​∑τ=1m∇ℒce(t,τ).Δsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑘𝜂superscriptsubscript𝜏2𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏1superscript𝛾𝜏𝑖1∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝑖𝜂1𝛾superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑚∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝜏\Delta\theta^{(t)}_{k}=-\eta\sum_{\tau=2}^{m}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{\tau-1}\gamma^{\tau-i+1}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,i)}\right)-\eta(1+\gamma)\sum_{\tau=1}^{m}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,\tau)}. Similar to the discussion regarding the update of bias in the output layer, we obtain

A.6 Derivation of the expected local update of Scaffold

The local update of Scaffold (Karimireddy et al., 2020) in local epoch τ𝜏\tau and global round t𝑡t can be found as

A.7 Derivation of the expected local update of FedProx

ℒprox=ℒce+λ2​‖θk(t,τ)−θ(t)‖2,subscriptℒproxsubscriptℒce𝜆2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝜏superscript𝜃𝑡2\mathcal{L}_{\text{prox}}=\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}+\frac{\lambda}{2}\left\|\theta_{k}^{(t,\tau)}-\theta^{(t)}\right\|^{2}, (64)

A.8 Derivation of the expected local update of FedDyn

The local objective function in FedDyn (Acar et al., 2021) is defined as

ℒdyn(t,τ)=ℒce−⟨∇ℒce(t−1,m),θk(t,τ)⟩+λ2​‖θk(t,τ)−θ(t)‖2,superscriptsubscriptℒdyn𝑡𝜏subscriptℒce∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝜏𝜆2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝜏superscript𝜃𝑡2\mathcal{L}_{\text{dyn}}^{(t,\tau)}=\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}-\left\langle\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t-1,m)},\theta_{k}^{(t,\tau)}\right\rangle+\frac{\lambda}{2}\left\|\theta_{k}^{(t,\tau)}-\theta^{(t)}\right\|^{2}, (71)

where θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)} is the global model used to initialize local training; θk(t,τ)subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝜏𝑘\theta^{(t,\tau)}_{k} is the local model of client k𝑘k in local epoch τ𝜏\tau and θk(t,1)=θ(t)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{k}^{(t,1)}=\theta^{(t)} ; ∇ℒdyn(t−1,m)∇superscriptsubscriptℒdyn𝑡1𝑚\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{dyn}}^{(t-1,m)} is the gradient of ℒdyn(t−1,m)superscriptsubscriptℒdyn𝑡1𝑚\mathcal{L}_{\text{dyn}}^{(t-1,m)} in the previous global round; λ𝜆\lambda is a hyper-parameter; m𝑚m denotes the total number of local epochs. According to the first-order condition for local optima,

∇ℒce(t,τ)−∇ℒce(t−1,m)+λ​(θk(t,τ)−θ(t))=0,∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡𝜏∇superscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡1𝑚𝜆superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝜏superscript𝜃𝑡0\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t,\tau)}-\nabla\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t-1,m)}+\lambda\left(\theta_{k}^{(t,\tau)}-\theta^{(t)}\right)=0, (72)

and thus the partial gradient of ℒcesubscriptℒce\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}} in local epoch m𝑚m can be computed as

=∂ℒce(t−2,m)∂𝐛j−λ​(𝐛j(t−1,m)−𝐛j(t−1,1))−λ​(𝐛j(t,m)−𝐛j(t,1))absentsuperscriptsubscriptℒce𝑡2𝑚subscript𝐛𝑗𝜆superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡11𝜆superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡1\displaystyle=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}^{(t-2,m)}}{\partial\mathbf{b}_{j}}-\lambda\left(\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t-1,m)}-\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t-1,1)}\right)-\lambda\left(\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t,m)}-\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t,1)}\right)

Appendix B Experimental Details

B.1 Comparison with Prior Works

We qualitatively summarize capabilities of the state-of-the-art label recovery methods in Table 5. A check mark (✔) indicates that a method is suitable for a given setting while the cross mark (✗) indicates that it is not. As the table indicates, RLU is capable of operating in a variety of scenarios.

B.2 Experimental Settings

B.2.1 General Settings

We used Pytorch (Paszke et al., 2019) to implement all the described experiments. In the experiments involving SVHN, the clients used LeNet (LeCun et al., 1998), a convolutional neural network with 161616 convolution layers and 5×5555\times 5 kernel, as the classifier. The batch size was set to 323232 in all experiments on SVHN. In the experiments involving CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, the clients trained Vgg-16 (Simonyan & Zisserman, 2014) with different scales of convolution kernel as the classifier. The batch size was set to 646464 and 256256256 in the experiments on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. In the experiments involving Tiny-ImageNet, the clients learned a standard ResNet-50 (He et al., 2016) where the batch size was set to 256256256. The number of clients was set to 101010 across all the experiments.

B.2.2 Settings of the Experiments in Table 2

The learning rate η𝜂\eta for the SGD optimizer was set to 0.010.010.01 in all experiments reported in Table 2. In order to obtain high level of data heterogeneity, we set the concentration parameters α𝛼\alpha to 0.50.50.5 in the experiments on SVHN and CIFAR10; in the experiments on CIFAR100 and Tiny-ImageNet, this parameter was set to 0.10.10.1. There are two groups of experiments in Table 2; in one the number of local epochs m𝑚m was set to 111, while in the other it was set to 101010. For the experiments involving multiple local epochs, the number of iterations T𝑇T in Alg. 2 was set to 101010.

B.2.3 Settings of the Experiments in Table LABEL:table3

Here we explored the effect of data heterogeneity controlled by varying the concentration parameter α𝛼\alpha from 0.050.050.05 to 555. For a fair comparison, we set the number of local epochs to m=10𝑚10m=10; other settings were identical to the settings in Table 2.

B.2.4 Settings of the Experiments in Table 4, Figure 1 and Figure 2

Similar to Table 2 and Table LABEL:table3, we set the number of local epochs m𝑚m to 101010 in all experiments reported in Table 4, Figure 1 and Figure 2. The concentration parameter α𝛼\alpha was set to 0.50.50.5 on SVHN/CIFAR10 and to 0.10.10.1 on CIFAR100. The learning rate η𝜂\eta was set to 0.010.010.01 in experiments on SVHN and to 0.050.050.05 in experiments on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100.

B.2.5 Settings of the Experiments in Gradients Inversion Attack

We conducted gradients inversion attack on the training set of CIFAR10 with an untrained ResNet32 model. We follow the strategy in IG (Geiping et al., 2020), using cosine similarity as the distance between ground-truth gradients and the estimated gradients computed using reconstructed images and labels. The batch size was set to 999 and the number of iterations for optimizing the reconstructed images and labels was set to 240002400024000. We used Adam (Kingma & Ba, 2014) optimizer and set the learning rate to 0.10.10.1. We also added the total variation regularization (Yin et al., 2021) to the objective function to create more realistic images with a weight scalar 0.20.20.2.

B.3 Empirical Validation of Assumption 3.1

To verify Assumption 3.1, we perform inference on the training set of SVHN and CIFAR10 using the global model across different training rounds. We collect the j𝑗j-th component of the output logits for the samples with label n𝑛n, and organize them into 100100100 bins to generate histograms. In each histogram, x-axis indicates the values of the j𝑗j-th component of the output logits while the values on y-axis indicate the corresponding number of samples. As shown in Figures 4 and 7, means 𝝁n,jsubscript𝝁𝑛𝑗\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j} of the randomly initialized global model are close to 00 regardless of their sign. As the training accuracy of the global model improves, the means 𝝁j,jsubscript𝝁𝑗𝑗\boldsymbol{\mu}_{j,j} increase to larger positive values while 𝝁n,j​(n≠j)subscript𝝁𝑛𝑗𝑛𝑗\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}(n\not=j) decreases to negative values, as shown in Figures 4-9.

B.4 Evaluation Metrics

We follow the strategy in iRLG (Ma et al., 2023), evaluating all methods in terms of class-level accuracy (cAcc) and instance-level accuracy (iAcc). Specifically, cAcc indicates the proportion of correctly recovered classes while iAcc indicates the proportion of correctly recovered labels. Suppose 𝐲csubscript𝐲𝑐\mathbf{y}_{c} denotes the ground-truth classes that appear in the batches while 𝐲^csubscript^𝐲𝑐\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{c} denotes the estimated classes; then cAcc can be computed as

cAcc​(𝐲^c,𝐲c)=|𝐲^c​ XNOR ​𝐲c|N,cAccsubscript^𝐲𝑐subscript𝐲𝑐subscript^𝐲𝑐 XNOR subscript𝐲𝑐𝑁\textbf{cAcc}(\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{c},\mathbf{y}_{c})=\frac{|\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{c}\textbf{ XNOR }\mathbf{y}_{c}|}{N}, (91)

where N𝑁N is the total number of classes. Similarly, suppose 𝐲isubscript𝐲𝑖\mathbf{y}_{i} denotes the ground-truth labels in the batches while 𝐲^isubscript^𝐲𝑖\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{i} denotes estimated labels; then iAcc can be computed as

iAcc​(𝐲^i,𝐲i)=|𝐲^i∩𝐲i|m⋅|ℬ|,iAccsubscript^𝐲𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖subscript^𝐲𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖⋅𝑚ℬ\textbf{iAcc}(\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i})=\frac{|\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{i}\cap\mathbf{y}_{i}|}{m\cdot|\mathcal{B}|}, (92)

where |𝐲^i|=|𝐲i|=m⋅|ℬ|subscript^𝐲𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖⋅𝑚ℬ|\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{i}|=|\mathbf{y}_{i}|=m\cdot|\mathcal{B}| and m𝑚m denotes the number of local epochs.

B.5 Visualization of Data Heterogeneity

We follow the strategy in (Yurochkin et al., 2019), utilizing Dirichlet distribution to generate heterogeneous data partitions from the original datasets. Specifically, we assign different proportions 𝐩k(j)superscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘𝑗\mathbf{p}_{k}^{(j)} of samples with label j𝑗j in the local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} to K𝐾K clients according to

𝐩(j)={𝐩k(j),k∈[K]}∼DirK​(α),superscript𝐩𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝐾similar-tosubscriptDir𝐾𝛼\mathbf{p}^{(j)}=\{\mathbf{p}_{k}^{(j)},k\in[K]\}\sim\textbf{Dir}_{K}(\alpha), (93)

where α𝛼\alpha is the concentration parameter that controls the level of heterogeneity. The number of samples with label j𝑗j in client k𝑘k’s local dataset can be computed as

Nk(j)=𝐩k(j)∑iK𝐩i(j)​N(j),superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑘𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐩𝑖𝑗superscript𝑁𝑗N_{k}^{(j)}=\frac{\mathbf{p}_{k}^{(j)}}{\sum_{i}^{K}\mathbf{p}_{i}^{(j)}}N^{(j)}, (94)

where N(j)superscript𝑁𝑗N^{(j)} is the number of samples with label j𝑗j in the overall training dataset. Figures 10 and 11 show the class distribution of clients’ local dataset by color-coding the number of samples: the darker the color, the larger the number of samples with the corresponding label. As shown in Figures 10 and 11, clients own only 2 or 3 classes in their local dataset given α=0.05𝛼0.05\alpha=0.05 while α=5𝛼5\alpha=5 leads to more balanced class distribution.

Appendix C Algorithms

C.1 RLU Algorithm

In this section, we formalize the RLU algorithm as Alg.1. In the standard paradigm in federated learning, the server broadcasts the global model 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} to selected clients; these clients then initialize their local model 𝜽k(t)superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)} to start local training. After m𝑚m local epochs, each client k𝑘k computes the local update Δ​𝜽k(t)=𝜽k(t)−𝜽(t)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡superscript𝜽𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} including Δ​𝐖k(t)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐖𝑘𝑡\Delta\mathbf{W}_{k}^{(t)} and Δ​𝐛k(t)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑘𝑡\Delta\mathbf{b}_{k}^{(t)}. For convenience, we omit the subscript k𝑘k in Δ​𝐖k(t)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐖𝑘𝑡\Delta\mathbf{W}_{k}^{(t)} and Δ​𝐛k(t)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑘𝑡\Delta\mathbf{b}_{k}^{(t)} in Alg.1. According to the formulated problem in Section 3.1, the learning rate η𝜂\eta in local training is known by the server. While preparing to conduct label recovery attack, the server estimates 𝝁n(t),Σn(t),𝒮n,j(t),𝝁n,j(t+1),Σn(t+1)superscriptsubscript𝝁𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡superscriptsubscript𝝁𝑛𝑗𝑡1superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑛𝑡1\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}^{(t)},\Sigma_{n}^{(t)},\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t)},\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}^{(t+1)},\Sigma_{n}^{(t+1)}, and 𝒮n,j(t+1),∀n,j∈[N]superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡1for-all𝑛𝑗delimited-[]𝑁\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t+1)},\forall n,j\in[N] via Monte Carlo method according to Eq. 8 with the global model 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}, updated local model 𝜽k(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k} and the auxiliary dataset 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. If m=1𝑚1m=1, the server simply solves the least-squares problem described in Eq. 10. If m>1𝑚1m>1, the server first solves the least-squares problem using coefficients computed as the mean of 𝒮n,j(t)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t)} and 𝒮n,j(t+1)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡1\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t+1)} to obtain a crude estimate. Then the server conducts posterior search (Alg. 2) to adjust the estimated N(t)superscript𝑁𝑡N^{(t)} as discussed in Section 3.2.2.

C.2 Posterior Search Algorithm

In Alg. 2, we simulated the dynamics of 𝝁n(t)superscriptsubscript𝝁𝑛𝑡\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}^{(t)} during local training. First, the server estimates average embedded signal 𝐞¯¯𝐞\bar{\mathbf{e}} according to Eq. 14. Using the crude estimates of N(t)superscript𝑁𝑡N^{(t)} and 𝒮n,j(t)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛𝑗𝑡\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t)} as inputs, the server computes Δ​𝐛j(t,τ)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑡𝜏\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t,\tau)} according to Eq. 12. Subsequently, the server computes Δ​𝝁n,j(t,τ)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝝁𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏\Delta\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)} using 𝐞¯¯𝐞\bar{\mathbf{e}}, and then estimates 𝝁^n,j(t,τ+1)superscriptsubscript^𝝁𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏1\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau+1)}. Recursively, repeating the procedure, the server finally obtains 𝝁^n,j(t,τ+1)superscriptsubscript^𝝁𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏1\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau+1)}. Based on the difference between 𝝁^n,j(t,τ+1)superscriptsubscript^𝝁𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏1\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau+1)} and 𝝁n,j(t,τ+1)superscriptsubscript𝝁𝑛𝑗𝑡𝜏1\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau+1)}, the server can calibrate/improve estimated N(t)superscript𝑁𝑡N^{(t)}.
